instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2519: What is 820-2519? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CPU_VCORE: What is CPU_VCORE? Power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.P3V3S3_EN: What is P3V3S3_EN? P3V3S3_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_S3 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP3V3S3_EN: What is PP3V3S3_EN? PP3V3S3_EN is a typo of P3V3S3_EN, which is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_S3 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2519</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, s0, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No liquid damage. Very clean board. Wont turn on. 

G3h - 12.56V
<SIGNAL>S5_HS_COM</SIGNAL> - 12.56V
<SIGNAL>S5_HS_OTH</SIGNAL> - 12.56V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 16.37V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> -5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - problems
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_T29</SIGNAL> - .836V (line is not shorted; does this matter in this situation?)
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0.1V

When this came in this had no VCORE and I was troubleshooting <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> for <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> for <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> for EN on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>. Now, I notice I keep losing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>. I have replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> and regained <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> for about 60 seconds, fans were spinning but still no <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>. Then soon lost <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> again. Im assuming if I replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> it will come back. But I am assuming I will most likely lose it again. <RESISTOR>R7975</RESISTOR> was ripped off, and has been replaced. If I'm way off please let me know. Thanks, have a good one bro, appreciate it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2519</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, s0, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Why are you not checking <SIGNAL>P3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL>  and <SIGNAL>P3V3S3_SS</SIGNAL>. Blindly replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> is not using brains.
Also if <RESISTOR>R7975</RESISTOR> was ripped off, someone already fucked with this board and anything can be wrong with it. GPU still original edge bonding? Serial number sticker on RAM slot?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2519</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, s0, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hey Duke. Not blind. I assumed because I had 3v3 on pins 2,.3 and 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> and nothing on pin 1 (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>) that <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> was my issue. Isnt this where it (<SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>) is created? Maybe Im confused. Please help me understand. GPU edge bonding is still original. No burn marks in the area. RAM sticker in tact. Resistor was ripped off as if someone had removed the board carelessly and maybe slipped with a screw driver putting it back in. Thank you Duke.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2519</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, s0, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Oh so you have 3V on pin 3 so yeah then <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> would never open. <SIGNAL>P3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2519</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, s0, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi. Yes. I had 3v on pin 3 and <SIGNAL>PP3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL> was not present. When I remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> for a like 10 seconds and put it back on, pin 3 becomes 0 and <SIGNAL>PP3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL> is present giving me <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> & S0. This does not stay. After I unplug the power and plug it back in I'm back to 3v on pin 3 and <SIGNAL>PP3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL> not present. Now, even with my 3v rails being present , I still did not get CPUVCORE. Checked <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> and found I was only getting .361V on <SIGNAL>VMON_Q4_BASE</SIGNAL>. Though I was getting 3.3V on pin 6, 1.074V on pin 5, 1.497V on pin 7 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>. All this doesnt matter because once i unplug I lose my 3V S3 rail. What changes when I remove this chip? Thanks Duke.


Update -

<TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR> (non working state)

pin1 - 0
pin2 - 0
pin3 - 3.3V
pin4 - 0
pin5 - 0
pin6 - 3.2- 3.0V. It fluctuates up and down. Mostly down.

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> are missing in this state.

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2519</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, s0, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If pin 6 is fluctuating then I bet <SIGNAL>P3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL> is doing that too, there is no other way it could happen. Is PPBUS and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> stable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2519</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, s0, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I came in and pin 6 is steady now. Im not sure why it was fluctuation yesterday but it was slightly, not now. PPBUS is steady at 12.54V and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is holding at 3.351V.
I removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR> to check <SIGNAL>PP3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL> without it and plugged in power, fans go high and I have 3.3V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL>. This only lasted for about ten seconds, then board shut off and <SIGNAL>PP3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL> and was gone. I disconnected power and plugged back in, and the same thing occured but this time only for a couple seconds. Thanks alot. Have a good day.

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is also gone, which is where schematic says <SIGNAL>PP3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL> comes from.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2519</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, s0, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I honestly have no idea. Seeing as this thing was already pre-fucked it could be absolutely anything. If the RAM slot has no serial number sticker then it is a refurb board and can go in the trash for sure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2519</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, s0, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Got it working and VCORE as well, but VCORE is low. I measured at 7530 and got .765V with 4 OHM resistance to ground. I get very nervous around this area because I have fucked up before messing with the transistors. Any thoughts or suspects before I proceed? Thanks.

*L7530. Sry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2519</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, s0, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 0.75V on Vcore is fine. USB  mouse lighting up? Why is it working now all of a sudden?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2519</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, s0, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Kind of discouraging. Noticed it working after replacing <CAPACITOR>C7912</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7912</RESISTOR>. Also, I got thrown off because it wasnt doing the 2 fan spin thing to let me know it was working. It would do 1 short fan spin then shut down. Then i would have to unplug and plug back in to get steady fan spin and <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>. Because I also was missing VCORE? Anyway all is good. Thanks.
